captions.text: Sadness is part of the human experience,

but for centuries there has 
been vast disagreement

over what exactly it is and what,
if anything, to do about it.
In its simplest terms,
sadness is often thought of

as the natural reaction 
to a difficult situation.

You feel sad when a friend moves away
or when a pet dies.
When a friend says, "I'm sad,"

you often respond by asking,
"What happened?"

But your assumption that sadness
has an external cause outside the self
is a relatively new idea.

Ancient Greek doctors didn't
view sadness that way.

They believed it was a dark fluid
inside the body.
According to their humoral system,

the human body and soul were controlled
by four fluids, known as humors,

and their balance directly influenced
a person's health and temperament.

Melancholia comes from
melaina kole,

the word for black bile,
the humor believed to cause sadness.

By changing your diet
and through medical practices,

you could bring your humors
into balance.

Even though we now know
much more about the systems
that govern the human body,
these Greek ideas about sadness
resonate with current views,

not on the sadness we all
occasionally feel,
but on clinical depression.

Doctors believe that certain 
kinds of long-term,

unexplained emotional states are at least
partially related to brain chemistry,

the balance of various chemicals 
present inside the brain.
Like the Greek system,

changing the balance of these chemicals
can deeply alter

how we respond to even extremely
difficult circumstances.

There's also a long tradition
of attempting to discern
the value of sadness,
and in that discussion,

you'll find a strong argument
that sadness is not only

an inevitable part of life
but an essential one.
If you've never felt melancholy,

you've missed out on part of
what it means to be human.

Many thinkers contend that melancholy
is necessary in gaining wisdom.
Robert Burton, born in 1577,

spent his life studying the causes
and experience of sadness.

In his masterpiece
"The Anatomy of Melancholy,"

Burton wrote, "He that increaseth wisdom
increaseth sorrow."

The Romantic poets of 
the early 19th century

believed melancholy allows us to more
deeply understand other profound emotions,
like beauty and joy.

To understand the sadness of the trees
losing their leaves in the fall

is to more fully understand the cycle
of life that brings flowers in the spring.

But wisdom and emotional intelligence seem
pretty high on the hierarchy of needs.

Does sadness have value on
a more basic, tangible,
maybe even evolutionary level?

Scientists think that crying
and feeling withdrawn

is what originally helped our
ancestors secure social bonds
and helped them get the support they needed.

Sadness, as opposed to anger or violence,
was an expression of suffering

that could immediately bring people closer
to the suffering person,

and this helped both the person
and the larger community to thrive.

Perhaps sadness helped generate
the unity we needed to survive,

but many have wondered whether
the suffering felt by others

is anything like the suffering
we experience ourselves.
The poet Emily Dickinson wrote,

"I measure every Grief I meet
With narrow, probing Eyes -

I wonder if it weighs like MIne -
Or has an Easier size."
And in the 20th century,

medical anthropologists,
like Arthur Kleinman,

gathered evidence from the way
people talk about pain

to suggest that emotions aren't
universal at all,

and that culture, particularly the way
we use language,
can influence how we feel.
When we talk about heartbreak,

the feeling of brokenness 
becomes part of our experience,

where as in a culture that talks 
about a bruised heart,

there actually seems to be a different
subjective experience.

Some contemporary thinkers 
aren't interested

in sadness' subjectivity 
versus universality,

and would rather use technology to
eliminate suffering in all its forms.

David Pearce has suggested
that genetic engineering
and other contemporary processes

cannot only alter the way humans
experience emotional and physical pain,

but that world ecosystems 
ought to be redesigned
so that animals don't suffer in the wild.

He calls his project 
"paradise engineering."

But is there something sad about
a world without sadness?
Our cavemen ancestors and favorite poets

might not want any part 
of such a paradise.

In fact, the only things about sadness
that seem universally agreed upon

are that it has been felt by most
people throughout time,
and that for thousands of years,

one of the best ways we have to deal
with this difficult emotion

is to articulate it, to try to express
what feels inexpressable.
In the words of Emily Dickinson,

"'Hope' is the thing with feathers -
That perches in the soul -

"And sings the tune without the words -
And never stops - at all -"

This video annoys me a bit though because it speaks like removing pain isn't even possible, when in point of fact we know that it's so easy to totally annihilate physical pain that it happens by accident.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congenital_insensitivity_to_pain

"There are three mutations in SCN9A: W897X, located in the P-loop of domain 2; I767X, located in the S2 segment of domain 2; and S459X, located in the linker region between domains 1 and 2. This results in a truncated non-functional protein. Nav1.7 channels are expressed at high levels in nociceptive neurons of the dorsal root ganglia. As these channels are likely involved in the formation and propagation of action potentials in such neurons, it is expected that a loss of function mutation in SCN9A will lead to abolished nociceptive pain propagation.[3]"

That is not a chunk of theory or speculation, obviously.

Drug use alone both sanctioned and illegal probably seals the deal of the majority of humanity.

Even a cup of coffee or a hamburger is that trade-off on a smaller scale.

The moment a bio hacker can give me these mutations I'll do what is required to acquire them. I'd rather get them at my doctor's office but by the time they come around we'll be operating cruise subs on Europa.

+Brandon Sergent
Humans can't be empathetic and logical at the same time.(
http://www.popsci.com.au/science/humans-cant-be-empathetic-and-logical-at-the-same-time,378496) 
They're two diametrically opposing concepts because; a person with a 
logical temperament would see no reason to stop and comfort the crying 
child - instead, they would find a practical means to solve the child's 
issue. If the child were just crying because their toy broke; great, buy 
them a new one, problem solved. But, if the child were crying because their 
pet dog died, buying them a new dog wouldn't suffice to fill their 
sentimental void - sometimes they just need someone with an Empathetic 
temperament to comfort them, cry with them, and 'feel the feels' with them. 
It goes without saying that Empathetic and Logical temperaments both come 
with strengths and weaknesses.

Writers, artists and musicians exist to explore and provoke our emotions, 
and a great portion of them explore the beauty of melancholy; 
sad music, sad art, sad poems all exist for a reason.
Edgar Allan Poe's poem, 'The Raven' was crafted with the mood of melancholy 
well in mind.
“Beauty is the sole legitimate province of the poem” in general, and “The 
Raven” in particular, “Melancholy is thus the most legitimate of all 
poetical tones.” - Edgar Allan Poe.
To denounce the worthiness of melancholy is to denounce a great portion of 
the art world.
The very existence of art seems to clash with logic and productivity - a 
writer sitting around writing melancholic poems doesn't seem a rational 
thing to do, but it carries great purpose.  
We need the irrationality of emotion, even at times, if it compromises 
productivity, because emotion is greatly linked with the purpose of our 
existence, and life aint all about productivity.
Replace the humans on earth with highly productive yet emotionless robots; 
watch them advance greatly in technology - but to what end?
If they can't feel, then what's the point?
  
If you're blind to the beauty of melancholy in art, then it would tell me a 
lot about you; that you lack a certain capacity for emotional depth. I 
don't intend to come off as elitist, but from my history of greatly 
admiring the beauty of sadness and knowing a great many other individuals 
whom perceive this beauty too - I can't help but sense a disparity.   

(Btw are you familiar with MBTI? Because you come off as an XNTJ type.)

comments.text:
+Careful Icarus 
*"If 100% positive emotion were possible..."*

It is.

*"...extremely positive people aren't as good as empathy:"*

That's more vagary and loaded terms. The painless adaptive mind does not 
exist yet. Finding isolated configurations where happy people are 
maladaptive at any scale does not undermine the value of happiness itself.

In effect you're deploying a straw man argument, like the whole of brave 
new world.

http://www.hedweb.com/huxley/bnw.htm (This is not homework, it's recreation 
I assure you.)

*"Melancholy isn't just suffering; it's acknowledging the unfortunate state 
of the world rather than ignoring it to stay positive."*

No, melancholy is an unpleasant emotion that exists independently of 
context or intellectual choice.

Does Data from Star Trek need melancholy to make him act for the good? Does 
a dispassionate scientist need to weep at the suffering of the world to 
develop a cure that lessens it? No. We aren't roaches. Tickling our feelers 
isn't the only thing that moves us anymore.

This is an old and busted debate. Essentially you are taking the equivalent 
of the religious position that without the fear of hell there would be no 
kindness.

Such logic tells me more about you than it tells you about me. The bottom 
line is that humans can act in any way under any emotional conditions. 
That's the whole point of consciousness and a neocortex, to allow us a 
class of responses not married exclusively to stimulus.

*"Do you see how positivity and acknowledging the fortunate state of the 
world clash?"*

You're painting a false dichotomy, just like brave new world, that the only 
choices are intelligent tears or grinning idiocy.

To put it gently in the extreme, you lack imagination. Which ironically, is 
another thing that would be handily addressed by engineering paradise.

comments.text:
+Careful Icarus Are you quoting someone? Are you making an argument?

You seem to imply a purely mercenary defense of this particular flavor of 
suffering.

To respond to that for the record whether anyone was asserting that or not: 
I say we are not ants and usefulness is not the end all be all.

Besides, if the state of things is enjoyable, healthy, and stable, I say 
run with it until your intellect tells you to seek change. If it ain't 
broke don't fix it. The status quo is not inherently bad. Humanity has 
proven time and again that even in a state of joy and health they'll look 
for ways to make things even better.

Drunks for example famously scurry around looking for way to compound the 
high. (Food, sex, more booze.) Rich people don't stop once they are rich. 
Fit people push themselves to literally Olympic levels, despite pain, not 
because of it. Etc.

Joy is far more evocative of positive diversity, if checking the status quo 
is the objective.

I'll go beyond that and assert that any negative emotional motivation 
effect has a pleasant emotional functional equivalent. And that's on top of 
an infinite set of possible intellectual motivations, which even if I'm 
wrong are more than enough to compensate for any imagined losses associated 
with the annihilation of all forms of suffering.

(Un)happiness and the meaning of life might seem separate questions.  Yet 
as we become happier, life tends to become more meaningful. This increasing 
sense of meaning can shade - in cases of manic euphoria - to intense 
feelings of purpose and significance. Conversely, low mood is associated 
with a sense of emptiness and a loss of meaning, shading into the 
nihilistic feelings of severe depression. True, we sometimes speak of 
"empty hedonism". But if posthuman life is really animated by gradients of 
bliss, then most likely such life will be hyper-charged with significance.

Or in fewer words, take care of happiness, and the meaning of life will 
take care of itself.

comments.text:
Historian Lewis Namier once remarked how “One would expect people to 
remember the past and imagine the future, but in fact…they imagine the past 
and remember the future.” The "future" most of us remember is a blend of 
childhood science-fiction novels and Hollywood movies. Yes, life based on 
genetically pre-programmed gradients of bliss might be shallow, but such 
biohappiness might instead be rich, multi-faceted and profound. Coercive 
happiness? It's conceviable; the historical record suggests otherwise. 
Perhaps compare today's biology of involuntary suffering. Would life 
animated by gradients of intelligent bliss be "boring"? Biotechnology 
promises to abolish the molecular signature of boredom, making such states 
impossible. Future life may be driven by information-sensitive gradients of 
fascination. One again, biotechnology opens a menu of options. Either way, 
shouldn't we be free to choose?
